I once told a reporter that I thought markets were pretty
efcient. He quoted me as saying that markets are “self-
regulating.” Here is somebody with no clue about the
denition of the term (although I had explained its
denition). Informational efciency means one and only
one thing: prices reect available information.A simple
theory and
complex
factsThe efcient-markets theory did not become famous
because it is complex. The greatness of Fama’s
contribution lies in the fact that efcient-markets became
the organizing principle for decades of empirical work in
nancial economics. This empirical work taught us much
about the world, and in turn affected the world deeply.When you think of Fama, don’t think of Einstein, churning
out equations in the solitude of the Swiss patent ofce.
Think of Darwin, who also saw that a simple principle—
evolution by natural selection—organized and gave
purpose to a vast collection of facts. Fama is really most
famous for putting all the facts together, personally
collecting a lot of nch beaks, and guring out how the
curiosities collected by others t in to the framework, in
often challenging and unexpected ways.Furthermore, though the principle is simple, its
implications are often surprising, subtle, and remain
controversial to this day. Efciency implies that simple
trading rules (e.g. “buy when the market went up
yesterday”) should not work. This is a testable proposition,3/24/25, 4:45 PM Eugene F. Fama, Efficient Markets, and the Nobel Prize | Chicago Booth Review

and an army of nancial economists, including Gene,
checked it. The surprising empirical result is that trading
rules, technical systems, market newsletters, and so on
have essentially no power beyond that of luck to forecast
stock prices. This is not a theorem, an axiom, a
philosophy, or a religion: it is an empirical prediction that
could easily have come out the other way, and sometimes
does.Similarly, if markets are informationally efcient,
fundamental analysis performed by investment rms has
no power to select stocks, and professional active
managers should do no better at picking stock portfolios
than monkeys with darts. This is a remarkable
proposition. In any other eld of human endeavor,
seasoned professionals systematically outperform
amateurs. But other elds are not so ruthlessly
competitive as nancial markets.Many studies checked this proposition. It’s not easy.
Among other problems, you only hear from the winners.
Nobody writes articles celebrating the worst-performing
mutual fund manager. You need to collect data from the
losers, too, and separate luck from skill.
These studies found, surprisingly, that the data are much
closer to the efcient-markets prediction than anybody
thought. Professional managers do not systematically
outperform well-diversied passive investments. This
could easily have come out the other way. It would have
been lovely had it come out the other way. Academics who
earn our salaries teaching MBA students would be
delighted to instruct them that better knowledge and
training lead to more protable investment management.
Too bad the facts say otherwise.If markets are informationally efcient, corporate news
events such as earnings announcements should be
immediately reected in stock prices. Now, actually
checking stock-price reactions to corporate events is also
not as straightforward as it sounds. But Gene and his
coauthors provided the standard solution to all of the3/24/25, 4:45 PM Eugene F. Fama, Efficient Markets, and the Nobel Prize | Chicago Booth Review

empirical difculties that survive to this day. The
immense event-study literature followed, allowing
academic accounting to measure the effect of corporate
events by the associated stock price movements.
The practical implications of the nding that markets are
surprisingly efcient are enormous. The rise of the index
fund owes much to efciency. Without efciency, we
might all be invested with high-fee active managers who
promise us higher returns at someone else’s expense.
Standard procedures in accounting, regulation, and law
now routinely presume that asset prices are the best
measure of value.Are markets completely efcient? No, and Gene said so in
his very rst article. Efciency, like all perfect-competition
supply-and-demand economics, is an ideal, which real-
world markets can only approach. Empirical work can nd
only how close to or far from the ideal a given market is.
Bringing
science to
ﬁnanceToo much nance is ex post storytelling, with not much
more content than “markets went up—the gods must be
pleased.” More than a theory, efcient-markets was the
banner for bringing scientic method to the study of
nancial markets. Rather than ask, “What are Warren
Buffett’s three secrets of success?” or interview the latest
soothsayer, researchers started to collect clean data, and
examine theories systematically and objectively. Gene
was the leader of this movement, and set the
methodological standard for how academics do empirical
research.3/24/25, 4:45 PM Eugene F. Fama, Efficient Markets, and the Nobel Prize | Chicago Booth Review

Perhaps the best way to illustrate the empirical content of
the efcient-markets hypothesis is to point out where it is
false. Event studies of the release of inside information
usually nd large stock-market reactions. Evidently, that
information is not fully incorporated ex ante into prices.
Restrictions on insider trading are somewhat effective.
When markets are not efcient, the tests verify the fact. A
theory that can be rejected is a real theory.These are only a few examples. The nancial world is full
of novel claims, especially that there are easy ways to
make money. Investigating each anomaly takes time,
patience, and sophisticated empirical skill. One has to
check whether the gains were not luck, and whether the
complex systems do not generate good returns by
implicitly taking on more risk.For nearly half a century, Gene Fama’s efcient-markets
framework has provided the organizing principle for
empirical nancial economics, and continues to do so. A
new round of studies is examining again the abilities of
fund managers, focusing on new ways of sorting the lucky
from the skillful in past data.Gene’s bottom line is always: Look at the facts. Collect the
data. Test the theory. Like astronomy, every time we look,
the world surprises us totally. And it will again.
John H. Cochrane is the AQR Capital Management
Distinguished Service Professor of Finance. This piece is
adapted from a longer post  on his blog, The Grumpy
Economist .

1 I. BACKGROUND AND QUALIFICATIONS 1 
Q1.  Please state your name and employer. 2 
A1.  My name is Douglas B. Jester. I am Managing Partner of 5 Lakes Energy, a Michigan 3 
limited liability corporation, located at PO Box 869, Northport, Michigan 49670.  4 
Q2.  On whose behalf is this testimony being offered?  5 
A2. I am testifying on behalf of the Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota.  6 
Q3.  Are you the same Douglas Jester wh o previously submitted direct testimony in this 7 
proceeding?   8 
A3. Yes. 9 
Q4.  Are you sponsoring any Schedule s in relation to your surrebuttal testimony ?  10 
A4. No.  11 
II. PURPOSE OF TESTIMONY 12 
Q5.  What is the purpose and scope of your testimony? 13 
A5. I am responding to the rebuttal testimony of John Quackenbush in support of the Petition 14 
of Minnesota Power in the present case. Mr. Quackenbush rebuts my direct testimony in this 15 
proceeding. 16 
III. RESPONSE TO JOHN QUACKENBUSH REBUTTAL TO MY DIRECT 17 
TESTIMONY 18 
Q6. Please summarize Mr. Quackenbush’s rebuttal to your direct testimony . 19 
A6. In his direct testimony in this case, Mr. Quackenbush testified about the Michigan Public 20 
Service Commission’s approval of the transfer of control of Upper Peninsula Power Company 21 
(“UPPCO”) to Balfour Beatty Infrastructure Partners in 2014  in settlement of Case No. U -17564 22 
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA-24-198 
OAH Docket No. 25-2500-40339 
Jester Surrebuttal 
2
 and the subsequent transfer of control of UPPCO to Axium UP Holdings LLC after settlement of 1 
Case No. U -20995. 2 
In my direct testimony, I reported that several subsequent UPPCO cases  before the Michigan 3 
Public Service Commission  were very contentious as UPPCO sought to recover significant cost 4 
increases related to the transfer of control  and sought a high cost of capital on its rate base. 5 
In rebuttal, Mr. Quackenbush walks through each of the issues I identified as contentious sequelae 6 
to the  UPPCO  transfer of control  and attempts to  represent that these issues were not a result of 7 
the transfer of control or that the Michigan Public Service Commission satisfactorily resolved the 8 
issue when presented.  The issues I raised in direct testimony that Mr. Quackenbush undertakes to 9 
rebut were:  10 
•UPPCO requested a large increase in its return on common equity, partly on the basis 11 
that it was now a small, higher -risk, utility than when it was a wholly owned subsidiary 12 
of Integrys . 13 
•UPPCO requested substantial increases in expenses to recover increases in pension 14 
costs, notwithstanding the representation of the parties in the transfer of control case 15 
that the UPPCO pension was fully funded by Integrys, which was compounded by an 16 
extremely high ratio of pensioners to employees that was not examined in the transfer 17 
of control case. 18 
•UPPCO reduced distribution system maintenance investment during the transfer of 19 
control and until its next rate case, then proposed a large increase for the future test 20 
year. 21 
•UPPCO requested substantial costs to increase staffing as it separated from shared 22 
management services previously provided by Integrys  as well as substantial costs for 23 
additional office space and for new information systems. 24 
•UPPCO was slow to terminate an above -market power purchase agreement with a 25 
previous affiliate utility .126

OAH Docket No. 25-2500-40339 
Jester Surrebuttal 
 
3 
 • UPPCO’s debt while it was owned by Balfour Beatty was entirely owed to Balfour 1 
Beatty through an affiliate transaction. In my opinion, the costs of that debt were 2 
persistently high compared to the costs of debt directly to various other Michigan 3 
utilities.  4 
Q7.  What is your reply to Mr. Quackenbush’s rebuttal testimony?   5 
A7. The significance of my direct testimony was that a commission considering authorizing a 6 
transfer of control should not take at face value an applicant’s claim that transfer of control will 7 
not cause an increase in rates but  should be diligent about considering possible issues the applicant 8 
might raise in the aftermath of obtaining control of a utility and  should address those in the transfer 9 
of control proceeding. Failure to do so leads to significant case costs for the commission and 10 
intervenors, some risk of rate increases caused by the transfer of control, and likely disappointment 11 
of expectations on the part of the investor that took control of the utility.  12 
Q8. What is your reply to Mr. Quackenbush  regarding UPPCO’s request for a large increase 13 
in its return on common equity  in the first UPPCO rate case following transfer of control?  14 
A8. Mr. Quackenbush characterizes the dispute about return on common equity in Michigan Public 15 
Service Commission Case No. U -17274 as routine and not a result of the transfer of control  of 16 
UPPCO.2 I agree that is not uncommon for utilities to propose increases in return on equity in rate 17 
cases, and for Commission’s to adjudicate  those proposals. The distinguishing feature of the 18 
argument about return on equity in this case was that most of the requested increase in return on 19 
equity was inclusion of a premium due to the risk associated with UPPCO being a small utility.  20 
But UPPCO had become a small utility as a result of  the transfer of control, when it had previously 21 
been controlled by a reasonably large utility holding company. Balfour Beatty either 22 
misrepresented their intentions  when they represented in  the transfer of control case that the 23 
transfer of control would not affect rates, or they reneged on that claim  when filing the next 24 
subsequent rate case. An expectation on this topic could have been included in the terms of the 25 
transfer of control settlement.  26

(“Quackenbush Rebuttal”),  28: 1- 15.

4 
 Q9. What is your reply to Mr. Quackenbush regarding UPPCO’s request for recovery of 1 
increases in pension costs?   2 
A9. Mr. Quackenbush acknowledges that pension costs were an issue in Michigan Public Service 3 
Commission Case No. U -17274 and represents this as a benign selection amongst alternatives 4 
proposed by UPPCO to deal with a newly established stand- alone pension plan.3 The fundamental 5 
issue about the pension in that case was that Integrys apparently placed every Integrys employee 6 
or pensioner that had worked for UPPCO into the new UPPCO pension plan, creating a pension 7 
plan with more  pensioners than active employees. Then UPPCO obtained a pension funding 8 
analysis after the transfer of control  that showed a substantial shortfall of pension assets relative 9 
to projected pension requirements. The result was a need for significant additional funding for the 10 
pension, for which UPPCO presented alternatives. Scrutiny of the arrangements for the new 11 
pension plan could have had greater scrutiny in the transfer of control case.  12 
Q10. What is your reply to Mr. Quackenbush regarding UPPCO’s  changes in distribution 13 
system maintenance investment around the transfer of control?   14 
A10. Mr. Quackenbush represents that the “timing of distribution system maintenance investment 15 
during the UPPCO transition” was not abnormal.4 The issue I raised in my direct testimony was 16 
that UPPCO , under Integrys control , appeared to  significantly reduce normal distribution system 17 
additions during the period when transfer of control was under consideration; then UPPCO , under 18 
Balfou r Beatty  control, accelerated investments to catch up on routine maintenance.  19 
According to UPPCO  FERC Form 1, Page 206, line  75, column (c)  for years  2013 through 2014 20 
and 2019 and thereafter  and FERC Form 1, Page 208(M), line 76, column (c)  for years 2015 21 
through 2018,5 the annual additions to distribution plant for UPPCO were as follows:  22

Bearing in mind that the transfer of control case was filed in late 2013 and settled in 2014, and the 2 
subsequent rate case was filed in September 2015 based on a projected test year  that mostly falls 3 
in 2017, this pattern is as I described. From 2014 through 2016, distribution system maintenance 4 
capital additions were lower, then increased as I described in my direct testimony. This behavior  5 
could have been addressed in the transfer of control case, with an expectation that  the sale of 6 
UPPCO was priced premised on routine maintenance investments  rather than post -sale catchup 7 
investments that would add to rates. 8 
Q11. What is your reply to Mr. Quackenbush regarding UPPCO’s increased staffing costs 9 
as it separated from shared management services previously provided by Integrys?   10 
A11.  Mr. Quackenbush simply uses his rebuttal on this issue to explain that this will not happen 11 
in the proposed transfer of control of ALLETE.6 I do not dispute nor agree with his position on 12 
this aspect of the proposed transfer of control of ALLETE in the present case. The fact remains 13 
that there were significant transition costs at UPPCO that were not accounted for in representations  14 
by the Applicants in the UPPCO transfer of control case —including Applicants’ representations  15 
that the transfer of control would not affect rates. Diligence during the transfer of control case 16 
could have uncovered these costs and informed the Commission’s decision about the transfer of 17 
control. 18 
Q12. What is your reply to Mr. Quackenbush regarding UPPCO’s  slowness in terminating 19 
an above- market power purchase agreement with a previous affiliate utility ?  20 
A12. Mr. Quackenbush asserts that my criticism of  UPPCO  on this matter simply reflects that the 21 
Commission did not agree with me.7 In fact, the problem was that UPPCO did not timely give 22

 notice of an intent to cancel. A commitment to cancellation could have been included in the  transfer 1 
of control case.  2 
Q13. What is your reply to Mr . Quackenbush regarding UPPCO’s cost of debt held by 3 
Balfour Beatty?  4 
A13. Mr. Quackenbush implicitly  dismisses this issue because my client  in various UPPCO cases , 5 
Citizens Against R ate Excess  (CARE) , did not pursue the issue. He also hastens to add that this 6 
will not be an issue with the ALLETE transfer of control, because ALLETE plans to borrow  from 7 
the public debt market.8 Given that CARE was highly resource constrained, Mr. Quackenbush’s 8 
implied critique is meaningless. I do not dispute or affirm his assertion that this issue will not arise 9 
in the case of ALLETE transf er of control in the present case. This issue, like the others discussed 10 
above, was to illustrate that a commission considering transfer of control should be diligent about 11 
exploring issues that might arise as a result of the transfer of control. 12 
IV. RECOMMENDATIONS  13 
Q14. Based on your experience in the UPPCO transfer-of- control cases, what d o you 14 
recommend to the Minnesota Commission?   15 
A14. In my direct testimony, I stated that “if the Commission approves the proposed transfer of 16 
control of ALLETE, I recommend that the Commission do so on the basis of an explicit financial 17 
structure that is rendered as explicit conditions on the transfer of control as well  as addressing 18 
other concerns the Commission may have about aspects of ALLETE’s current or near future 19 
operations.” I stand by that recommendation.   20

Dear Ms. Brama : 
 
Please accept this message as notiﬁcation that Commission Staff will be asking some questions at 
the upcoming evidentiary hearings related to MPUC Docket No. E-015/PA- 24-198  (OAH Docket No. 
25-2500 -40339 ). 
 
Questions we intend to ask are:  
1. Would Mr. Quackenbush  be willing to ﬁle into e -Dockets the 2024 10K  he references on 
page 3 of his March 4, 2025 Rebuttal Testimony ? 
2. Please reconcile the capital needs described in testimony in this proceeding with the 
capital needs as  described in the 10K ﬁling mentioned above , and  with  the capital needs 
that will be required as described in  the Company’s recently ﬁled Integrated Resource Plan 
(IRP)  in MPUC Docket No. E -015/RP -25-127 . 
3. How did the proposed transaction inﬂuence the planning of the IRP mentioned above?  
4. For any regulated utility where, independently or collectively, either the Canada Pension 
Plan Investment Board and/or Global Infrastructure Partners/Black Rock currently has an ownership interest of 40%  or more , please provide those utility’s capital structure before 
closing and its most current capital structure.  
5. For any regulated utility where, independently or collectively, either the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and/or Global Infrastructure Partners/Black Rock previously had, but 
no longer has, an ownership interest of 40% or more, please provide those utility’s capital 
structure before closing and its capital structure at the time of divesture.  
6. If the Commission were to approve the sale , would the “new Minnesota Power” accept the 
following conditions:  
A. Limit s to the capital structure  used for ratemaking purposes ? 
B. In the Company’s ﬁrst rate case after the acquisition, would the Company be willing to 
extend its statutory deadline for a ﬁnal Commission Order?  
C. 
Commit to using an “all -in” allocation for the determination of retail rates in future 
rate cases, where all transmission facilities revenues are used to oﬀset costs.  
So that these questions can be directed to the appropriate Company witnesses, Commission Staff requests that, at Friday’s conference call with the ALJ, the Company provide the information 
regarding which witnesses will be able to address these questions.  
Thank you.  
Sincerely,  
Robert Manning
